## Summary
- Rule available since: `v1.5.0`
- Diagnostic Category: [`lint/style/useForOf`](/reference/diagnostics#diagnostic-category)
- This rule isn't recommended, so you need to enable it.
- This rule doesn't have a fix.
- The default severity of this rule is [**information**](/reference/diagnostics#information).
- Sources: 
  - Same as [`@typescript-eslint/prefer-for-of`](https://typescript-eslint.io/rules/prefer-for-of)
  - Same as [`unicorn/no-for-loop`](https://github.com/sindresorhus/eslint-plugin-unicorn/blob/main/docs/rules/no-for-loop.md)

## How to configure
```json title="biome.json"
{
	"linter": {
		"rules": {
			"style": {
				"useForOf": "error"
			}
		}
	}
}

```
## Description
Prefer using `for...of` loops over standard `for` loops where possible.

This rule recommends using a `for...of` loop in place of a `for` loop
when the loop index is solely used to read from the iterated array.

### Exceptions for Index Usage

When the loop index is declared within the outer scope or used anywhere within the loop body,
it is acceptable to use a `for` loop.
(`Array.entries()` can be used to a similar effect.)

## Examples

### Invalid

```js
for (let i = 0; i < array.length; i++) {
  console.log(array[i]);
}
```

### Valid

```js
for (let item of array) {
   console.log(item);
 }
```

```js
for (let i = 0; i < array.length; i++) {
   // `i` is used, so for loop is OK
   console.log(i, array[i]);
 }
```

```js
for (let i = 0, j = 0; i < array.length; i++) {
   console.log(i, array[i]);
 }
```

```js
let i = 0;
for (; i < array.length; i++) {
   console.log(array[i]);
 }
```
